questions.text: Recurrent mobile hypopyon seen in acute anterior uveitis indicates:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Behcet's disease Behcet’s disease is an idiopathic multisystem disease characterized by recurrent non-granulomatous uveitis , aphthous ulceration , genital ulceration and erythema multiforme. This disease is typically affected in young men who are H LA B51 positive Uveitis is typically bilateral acute recurrent iridocyclitis associated with hypopyon it may be associated with posterior uveitis with periphlebitis retinae, retinitis

Highyeild:

BEHCET'S DISEASE It is an idiopathic multisystem disease characterised by recurrent, non-granulomatous uveitis, aphthous ulceration, genital ulcerations and erythema multiforme. It is still unknown; the basic lesion is an obliterative vasculitis probably caused by circulating immune complexes . The disease typically affects young men who are positive for HLA-B51 . Clinical features. Uveitis seen in Behcet's disease is typically bilateral, acute recurrent iridocyclitis associated with hypopyon. It may also be associated with posterior uveitis, vitritis, periphlebitis retinae and retinitis in the form of white necrotic infiltrates. Treatment: No satisfactory treatment is available, and thus the disease has got comparatively poor visual prognosis. • Corticosteroids may be helpful initially but the ultimate response is poor. • Immunosuppressive drugs such as methotrexate, azathioprine and cyclosporine are needed in resistant cases and for an acute flare.

Anterior uveitis. Typically presents as granulomatous iridocyclitis characterized by iris nodules, large mutton fat KPs (in a triangular distribution), anterior chamber cells and flare, and posterior synechiae. questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of pain and redness in both eyes. He has new blurry vision and difficulty opening his eyes in bright surroundings. He has not had any recent trauma. He uses contact lenses daily. He had surgery on his left eye 6 months ago after a penetrative trauma caused by a splinter. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows congestion of the perilimbal conjunctiva bilaterally. Visual acuity is decreased bilaterally. Ocular movements are normal. Slit-lamp examination shows a cornea with normal contours and leukocytes in the anterior chambers of both eyes. The eyelids, eyelashes, and lacrimal ducts show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.correct_answer: B. Autoimmune reaction against retinal antigens
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Autoimmune reaction against retinal antigens This patient has anterior uveitis, which typically manifests with bilateral eye pain and redness, photophobia, perilimbal congestion and hypopyon on slit-lamp examination. Sympathetic ophthalmia is an autoimmune reaction against retinal antigens that occurs days to years after a penetrating ocular injury or, less commonly, ocular surgery. Damage to the eye can sensitize the immune system to retinal antigens and subsequently cause bilateral granulomatous anterior uveitis. This manifests with bilateral eye pain, redness, and photophobia as seen in this case. Evidence of inflammation of the anterior chamber on slit lamp examination is typical. This patient is at risk of bilateral blindness; treatment with glucocorticoids should be initiated immediately.

Highyeild:

Sympathetic ophthalmia Etiology Predisposing factors: l. It almost always follows a penetrating injury . Wounds in the ciliary region ( the so-called dangerous zone) are more prone to it. Wounds with the incarceration of the iris, ciliary body or lens capsule are more vulnerable. It is more common in children than in adults. It does not occur when actual suppuration develops in the injured eye. Pathogenesis : Various theories have been put forward. The most accepted one is an allergic theory, which postulates that the uveal pigment acts as an allergen and excites plastic uveitis in the sound eye. Pathology It is characteristic of granulomatous uveitis, i.e. there is • Nodular aggregation of lymphocytes, plasma cells, epithelioid cells and giant cells scattered throughout the uveal tract. • Dalen-Fuchs' nodules are formed due to the proliferation of the pigment epithelium (of the iris, ciliary body and choroid) associated with invasion by the lymphocytes and epithelioid cells . • Sympathetic perivasculitis . The retina shows perivascular cellular infiltration. Clinical features Exciting (injured) eye. It shows clinical features of persistent low-grade plastic uveitis, which include ciliary congestion, lacrimation and tenderness. Keratic precipitates may be present at the back of the cornea ( dangerous sign ). Sympathizing (sound) eye. It is usually involved after 4-8 weeks of injury in the other eye . The earliest reported case is after 9 days of injury . Sympathetic ophthalmitis, almost always, manifests as acute plastic iridocyclitis . Rarely it may manifest as neuro retinitis or choroiditis. Clinical features of iridocyclitis in the sympathetic eye can be divided into two stages : Prodromal stage. Sensitivity to light (photophobia) and transient indistinctness of near objects (due to weakening of accommodation) are the earliest symptoms. In this stage, the first sign may be the presence of retrolental flare and cells or the presence of a few keratic precipitates (KPs) on the back of the cornea. Other signs include mild ciliary congestion, slight tenderness of the globe, fine vitreous haze and disc oedema which is seen occasionally. Fully-developed stage . It is clinically characterised by typical signs and symptoms consistent with acute plastic iridocyclitis

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A .Reactivation of herpes zoster virus within the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve causes herpes zoster ophthalmicus, which manifests with anterior uveitis as seen in this case. However, this condition typically causes unilateral symptoms, not bilateral symptoms. Moreover, this patient lacks additional manifestations of herpes zoster ophthalmicus such as cutaneous symptoms (e.g., vesicular rash) and fever. Option: C .Infection of the cornea with aeruginosa causes bacterial keratitis, which manifests with blurry vision, eye pain, and redness as seen in this case. In addition, this patient's contact lens use is a significant risk factor for this condition. However, the absence of purulent discharge and corneal ulcers on slit-lamp examination makes this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, bacterial keratitis rarely manifests with bilateral anterior uveitis. Option : D. Impaired drainage of aqueous humour can cause angle-closure glaucoma, which manifests with sudden-onset blurry vision, eye pain, and redness as seen in this case. However, this condition typically causes unilateral symptoms, not bilateral symptoms, and does not typically cause hypopyon. Moreover, this patient lacks additional manifestations of angle-closure glaucoma such as frontal headaches, nausea, and vomiting.

Extraedge:

Genetic predisposition to the development of sympathetic ophthalmia has also been proposed, with a particular focus on human leukocyte antigen (HLA). HLA-A11 antigen expression has been linked to patients with sympathetic ophthalmia, as well as HLA-DRB1*04, DQA1*03, and DQB1*04. Interestingly, similar associations have been recognized between HLA-D4, DQw3, and -DRw43 and VKH disease. (source:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3679835/)

questions.text: A 75-year-old white man underwent intracapsular cataract extraction 25 years ago. Approximately 15 years ago, he underwent secondary anterior chamber lens placement. Two years ago, he had a penetrating keratoplasty on this eye. Over the past year, he has had recurrent uveitis in this eye, and on referral evaluation in your office, his IOP is 25 mm Hg. Gonioscopy reveals an open angle and a small hyphema. The most appropriate management of his eye would be:

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical removal of his anterior chamber lens

questions.correct_answer: D. Surgical removal of his anterior chamber lens
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surgical removal of his anterior chamber lens Uveitis-glaucoma-hyphema syndrome is rarely seen today, but it was a common complication of older, rigid haptic anterior chamber lenses that suffered from poor design, poor finishing characteristics, or excessive mobility, allowing them to chafe the iris surface. Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy was also more common with these types of lenses . Modern flexible haptic anterior lenses are better tolerated and less apt to cause these complications. Therefore, because this patient's anterior chamber lens is causing problems, it should be removed or replaced. Uveitis Glaucoma Hyphema Syndrome UGH is a secondary inflammatory glaucoma classically related to IOL haptic rubbing ton the iris May occur from squared edge haptic in sulcus as well as scleral fixated IOLS In the bag IOLs may also cause UGH when the bag is unstable allowing for iris contact Triad of chronic inflammation, recurrent bleeding, iris TIDs and elevated IOP with occasional iris neovascularization and CME UBM is helpful to determine position of the IOL Gonioscopy for assessment of iris root and TM Treatment includes IOP lowering medications along with surgical repositioning or exchange of the IOL
